subject: Law
title: Privacy Rights in the Digital Age
description: One-minute skill: Privacy Rights in the Digital Age.

hook.text: The government can read your emails older than 180 days without a warrant. A 1986 law allows it.

buildup.text: The Constitution never mentions 'privacy.' Courts inferred it from the First, Third, Fourth, and Ninth Amendments.

discovery.text: The Third-Party Doctrine held that data shared with companies has no privacy protection. Courts are rethinking this.

twist.text: Modern life requires sharing data constantly. If sharing means losing privacy, the right effectively vanishes.

climax.text: Carpenter v. United States began shifting the doctrine, but most digital privacy law remains outdated.

punchline.text: The Constitution guards your home. Your data is another story.

quiz.question: What is the Third-Party Doctrine?
options: Three judges must agree on privacy cases
Data shared with companies loses privacy protection
Third parties can sue on your behalf
